''Luso-moçambicano'' |population= '''82,593''' (0.36% of the population)
{{flagicon|Mozambique}} 57,593 Mozambican citizens (2012)
{{flagicon|Portugal}} 25,000 Portuguese immigrants (2011)[http://www.observatorioemigracao.secomunidades.pt/np4/2454.html Observatório da Emigração] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303190314/http://www.observatorioemigracao.secomunidades.pt/np4/2454.html |date=2016-03-03 }} |popplace= [[Maputo]], [[Matola]], [[Beira (Mozambique)|Beira]], [[Pemba, Mozambique|Pemba]] |langs= [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Tsonga language|Xitsonga]], [[Makhuwa language|Makhuwa]], [[Ndau language|Ndau]] dialect of [[Shona language|Shona]], [[swahili language|Swahili]], and other [[Bantu languages]] |rels= [[Christianity]] (predominantly [[Roman Catholic]] with some [[Protestantism|Protestants]]) |related= [[Portuguese people]], [[Portuguese Brazilian]], [[white Brazilian]]s, [[Portuguese Africans]]}} '''Portuguese Mozambicans''' ({{lang-pt|luso-moçambicanos}}) are [[Mozambique|Mozambican]]-born descendants of [[Portuguese people|Portuguese settlers]]. ==History== Portuguese explorers turned to present-day [[Mozambique]] and two other [[Portuguese-speaking African countries|PALOP]] [[nations]] ([[Angola]] and [[Guinea-Bissau]]) to bring [[Black people|black]] [[slaves]] to [[Portugal]] before bringing them to work for their [[plantations]] in their [[Latin America]]n [[province]], the present-named [[Brazil]]. The first permanent Portuguese [[communities]] in the region were established in the 16th century. The whole region was divided into ''[[prazos]]'' ([[Estate in land|agricultural estates]]), to be lived by [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] [[settler]] families in the 17th century. [[Mozambique]] was declared a [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese province]] by the 19th century. By the early 20th century, the mainland government permitted more white emigration and settlement to the region, and Mozambique had 370,000 Portuguese settlers, who improved its economy, by the 1960s.Contrary to the other settlers which often had lived in Mozambique for two or even three generations, the Portuguese arriving during the last phase of colonial occupation did not become identified with Mozambique. It was during this time that [[António de Oliveira Salazar]] led Portugal, in which several thousands of Portuguese citizens fled to other countries, especially neighbouring [[Rhodesia]] and [[South Africa]] as well as [[Brazil]] and the [[United States]]. Blacks and some [[mulattos|''mestiços'']] and whites revolted against Portuguese rule in 1974. The [[Carnation Revolution|return to liberal democracy]] in Portugal led to the independence of its overseas colonies in 1975. By July 1975 around 80,000 Portuguese Mozambicans were left in the country from around 250,000 that lived in the country in the early 1970s. Of the 80,000 only around 10,000 opted for Mozambican citizenship instead of Portuguese citizenship. The most decisive factors for the preference for white emigration according to US diplomat William Jacobsen was a "combination of doctors leaving for good, plummeting standards of medical care... and uncertainty about country's willingness to allow Mozambican citizens to leave national territory."{{cite web | url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/news-and-analysis/the-anc-before-the-collapse-of-communism | title=The ANC before the collapse of Communism | publisher=Politicsweb | date=18 December 2013 | accessdate=6 April 2016 | author=James Myburgh}} Large numbers of Portuguese residents emigrated shortly after, most of them to Portugal, where they were called [[History_of_Portugal_(1974-1986)#The_retornados|''retornados'']], while others moved to neighbouring [[Malawi]], [[Rhodesia]], or [[South Africa]], and/or Brazil[https://imigrantes.no.sapo.pt/page6portugal.html Portuguese Immigration (History)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6GrrUiDTj?url=http://imigrantes.no.sapo.pt/page6portugal.html |date=2013-05-25 }} and the United States. Most notable legacy of Portuguese Mozambican settlers in South Africa is [[Nando's]], created in 1987, which incorporated influences from former Portuguese settlers from Mozambique, many of whom had settled on the south-eastern side of [[Johannesburg]], after Mozambique's independence in 1975. When the [[Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries]] was founded in 1996, many Portuguese and [[Portuguese Brazilian]]s arrived for economic and educational aid to Mozambique. They have helped increase Portuguese-language fluency especially in remote rural places and improved the economy, as the [[Mozambican Metical|metical]] has a large value converted from the [[Euro]]. Many among them have adopted the country as their permanent home. Many more Portuguese settlers returned from Portugal, it is estimated by the Mozambican embassy that about 6,000 returned. ==Language== Portuguese is the [[official language]] and [[lingua franca]] of Mozambique. Their dialect called [[Mozambican Portuguese]] is closer to Standard [[European Portuguese]] than [[Brazilian Portuguese|Brazilian dialects]]. Among them speak one of main [[Bantu languages]] (like [[Tsonga language|Xitsonga]], [[Makhuwa language|Makhuwa]], and [[Ndau language|Ndau]] dialect of [[Shona language|Shona]]) as second languages. Many educated Portuguese Mozambicans speak [[English language|English]], as it is an international lingua franca and Mozambique is a member of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]]. ==Religion== Most Portuguese Mozambicans are [[Christianity|Christians]] belonging to the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. ==Notable Portuguese Mozambicans== *[[Mia Couto]], well-known Mozambican writer *[[Tasha de Vasconcelos]], a Mozambican-Canadian model *[[Carlos Cardoso (journalist)|Carlos Cardoso]], murdered Mozambican journalist *[[Teresa Heinz]] *[[João Paulo Borges Coelho]], Mozambican historian and novelist *[[João Ubaldo Ribeiro|Joao Ribeiro]] *[[Amavel Pinto]] *[[Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho]], a Mozambican-Portuguese leader of the [[Carnation Revolution]] ==See also== * [[Portuguese Africans]] ** [[Portuguese Angolans]] ** [[Portuguese-South Africans]] * [[Portuguese Americans]] * [[Portuguese Brazilian]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913229-1,00.html MOZAMBIQUE: Dismantling the Portuguese Empire] {{Ethnic groups in Mozambique}} {{Portuguese diaspora}} [[Category:Mozambican people of Portuguese descent| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mozambique]] [[Category:Portuguese diaspora in Africa|Mozambican]]

According to the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]],<ref name=cpj1 /> Razzaq Gul was a member of the [[Baloch National Movement]] and secretary of the Press Club of Turbat.
Razzaq Gul was the 22nd journalist to have been murdered in the area of [[Balochistan]], listed as one of the most dangerous places for [[reporters]] in Pakistan,<ref name=express>{{cite news|last=Correspondent |first=Our |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/381540/journalist-killed-body-dumped-in-turbat/ |title=Journalist killed, body dumped in Turbat – The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=20 May 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> over a four-year period,<ref name=dawn>{{cite news|url=http://dawn.com/2012/07/09/22-balochistan-journalists-killed-in-four-years/ |title=22 Balochistan journalists killed in four years |publisher=Dawn (Pakistan) |date=9 July 2012 |accessdate=27 November 2012}}</ref> and he was one of eight Pakistani journalists killed since Jan 2011.<ref name=express2>{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/458292/threat-to-journalists-in-pakistan-alarms-reporters-without-borders/ |title=Threat to journalists in Pakistan alarms Reporters Without Borders – The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=30 October 2012 |accessdate=27 November 2012 }}</ref> Three days of demonstrations after his death began 1 June 2012 to protest his murder and impunity, the killing of journalists without investigation or prosecution.
== Personal == Razzaq Gul, 35, native of [[Pakistan]], was taken against his will and executed while working as a journalist in [[Turbat]], Pakistan. After being identified by his brother, Gul was buried in his hometown of Singhania Sir.<ref name=cpj2>{{cite web|last=Dietz |first=Bob |url=http://cpj.org/blog/2012/05/even-by-pakistani-standards-a-terrible-month-for-p.php |title=Even by Pakistani standards, a terrible month for press – Blog |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |date=24 May 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref>
== Career == Razzaq Gul was a television journalist<ref name=rsf>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/pakistan-fifth-murder-this-year-kidnap-22-05-2012,42660.html |title=Fifth murder this year, kidnap attempt and police violence – Reporters Without Borders |publisher=En.rsf.org |date= |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> covering war and politics for at least 10 years for [[Express News (Pakistan)|Express News]] in the [[Balochistan]] province in [[Turbat]], Pakistan.<ref name=expressprotest>{{cite news|last=Baloch |first=Shehzad |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/381842/protest-over-murder-of-journalist-razzaq-gul/ |title=Protest over murder of journalist Razzaq Gul – The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date= |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> Gul was the secretary of the Press Club located in [[Turbat]] and he was a member of the nationalist political organisation, [[Baloch National Movement]]<ref name=cpj2 />
== Death == Razzaq Gul was taken after leaving a press club on his way home on 18 May 2012.<ref name=frontierpost>{{cite news|url=http://www.thefrontierpost.com/article/162554/ |title=Missing journalist in Balochistan found dead |publisher=Thefrontierpost.com |date=20 May 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> His body was found the next morning, 19 May 2012, with at least 15 bullet holes and evidence of torture. The unknown assailants discarded the body close to the Old Civil Hospital located in [[Turbat]].<ref name=express />
{{Location map+ | Pakistan | AlternativeMap = Balochistan in Pakistan.svg | float = left | position = left | width = 300 | caption = The red shaded area is Balochistan, Pakistan, one of the four provinces of Pakistan. Mentioned locations within Pakistan relative to the capital Islamabad and the largest city Karachi. | alt = Turbat is located in Pakistan. | places = {{Location map~ | Pakistan | label = Islamabad |lat_deg = 33 | lat_min = 44 | lat_sec= 0 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 73 | lon_min = 6 |lon_sec= 0 | lon_dir = E}} {{Location map~ | Pakistan | label = Karachi | lat_deg = 24 | lat_min = 53 | lat_sec= 36 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 67 | lon_min = 1 | lon_sec= 39 | lon_dir = E}} {{Location map~ | Pakistan | label = Turbat | mark = Blue_pog.svg | lat_deg = 26 | lat_min = 0 | lat_sec= 15 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 63 | lon_min = 3 | lon_sec= 47 | lon_dir = E}} }}
== Context == The city of [[Turbat]], where Gul was found murdered, is located in the province of [[Balochistan]], where intense manoeuvres have been carried out by the Pakistani Military from 2001. The military wants to build temporary quarters for troops in the area which has been met by strong opposition from the citizens of the province due to the growing number of innocent people being killed. The [[Pakistan Air Force]] has bombed many of the districts in the region allegedly killing over 3000 people. Over 200,000 people have been forced to relocate to shelters due to the bombings.<ref name=humanrights.asia>{{cite news|url=http://www.humanrights.asia/news/urgent-appeals/UA-125-2007 |title=PAKISTAN: Four persons missing including a political activist and a journalist in Balochistan — Asian Human Rights Commission |language=ur |publisher=Humanrights.asia |date= |accessdate=9 October 2012}}</ref>
== Impact == Due to the violence in the [[Balochistan]] province, many reporters are scared to speak out. Razzaq Gul continued to report the facts even though journalists were being persecuted in his home country. Journalists are being targeted and murdered as a way to keep them from reporting the truth about the violent situation in this area of [[Pakistan]].<ref name=ifex>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifex.org/pakistan/2012/05/22/razzaq_gul/ |title=Abducted journalist found dead in Balochistan |publisher=IFEX |date=22 May 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> Research has placed [[Pakistan]] at the top of the list for countries posing the most danger to journalists .<ref name=guardian2>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade+world/pakistan |title=Greenslade + Pakistan | Media |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> Since 2008, there have been at least 27 reporters and news personnel executed in [[Pakistan]].<ref name=unesco>{{cite web|author=Source: |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/resources/news-and-in-focus-articles/all-news/news/director_general_deplores_murder_of_pakistani_journalists_abdul_razaq_gul_and_aurengzeb_tunio/ |title=Worldwide support to UNESCO's campaign "Women Make the News" | United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |publisher=Unesco.org |date=15 March 2005 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref>
== Reactions == Reaction to Razzaq Gul's murder was strong and swift. Owais Aslam Ali, secretary general of [[Pakistan Press International]], said journalists in [[Balochistan]] need protection to make it possible for them to report the facts as it has become almost impossible for them to do their jobs.<ref name=guardian1>{{cite news|last=Greenslade |first=Roy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2012/may/22/journalist-safety-pakistan |title=Pakistani journalist abducted and killed | Media | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date=22 May 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> Balochistan Union of Journalists called for a mourning period of three days which began 1 June 2012<ref name=cpj1>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/killed/2012/razzaq-gul.php |title=Razzaq Gul – Journalists Killed |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists |date= |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> Demonstrations took place in [[Turbat]] and surrounding areas with shops closing and protestors marching as they chanted for Gul's murderers to be brought to justice.<ref name=youtube>{{cite web|author=baloch warna |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fMmPiKGm2I8 |title=BHRO Demonstration in front of Karachi Press club. 22 May 2012 |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> The protesters said they did not want Razzaq Gul or any other innocent civilian or media worker to be just another name on a list of the dead that goes unsolved.<ref name=cpj1 />
[[Irina Bokova]], director-general of [[UNESCO]], said, "I condemn the killings of Abdul Razaq Gul and Aurengzeb Tunio who died alongside two companions. I urge the authorities to investigate these killings. It is essential for freedom of expression and for good governance that those responsible for the death of journalists be brought to justice." Other human rights groups called on Pakistani authorities to thoroughly investigate Gul's killing and bring the unknown assailants to justice, and the Acting Inspector General of Police Hussain Karar Khwaja initiated an investigation.<ref name=express /><ref name=alyunaniya>{{cite news|url=http://www.alyunaniya.com/number-of-journalists-killed-in-pakistan-rising/ |title=Number of journalists killed in Pakistan rising |publisher=AlYunaniya |date= |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref>
==See also== [[List of journalists killed during the Balochistan conflict (1947-Present)]]

{{Unreferenced|date=May 2009}} The Russian community in [[Greece]] are [[ethnicity|ethnic]] [[Russians]] living in Greece, and not the [[Greeks in Russia]] who immigrated to Greece in the 1990s.
There are 13,635 people of [[Russians|Russian]] origin living in Greece. Mostly in [[Athens]], [[Thessaloniki]] and [[Crete]]. A small part came in the 1920s after the [[Russian Civil War]], however the majority emigrated in the 1990s.

{{also|Painted pebbles (disambiguation){{!}}Painted pebbles}} [[File:Painted pebbles.jpg|thumb|right|Pictish painted pebbles]] '''Painted pebbles''' are a class of Early Medieval [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifact]] found in northern [[Scotland]] dating from the [[first millennium]] AD.
== Appearance == They are small rounded beach pebbles made of [[quartzite]], which have been painted with simple designs in a dye which is now dark brown in colour. The size varies from 18 mm by 22 mm to 65 mm by 51mm. It has not proven possible to analyse the dye itself from the stains that remain.
The [[Motif (visual arts)|motifs]] are carefully executed and the most common are dots and wavy lines. Other motifs are small circles, pentacles, crescents and triangles, showing strong relationships with the Pictish symbol stone motifs.<ref name="PSAS">{{harvnb|Ritchie|1972}}</ref>
Experimental archaeology suggests that the designs were likely to have been painted with peat tar.<ref>{{harvnb|Arthur|Murray|Ritchie|2014}}</ref>
== Distribution ==
To date, 55 painted pebbles have been found. 11 of these were found in [[Caithness]], 5 in [[Orkney]], 27 in [[Shetland]].<ref>{{harvnb|Arthur|Murray|Ritchie|2014}}</ref> Most have come from [[broch]] sites which have been shown to have had an extensive post-broch occupation. An [[ogham]]-inscribed spindle-whorl was associated with one find at Buckquoy in [[Orkney]] (see [[Buckquoy spindle whorl]]). Several have been associate with [[Wheelhouse (archaeology)|wheelhouse]]s or their outbuildings. An example was found at a Pictish site at Buckquoy in Orkney as reported in 1976. It had the "small ring" type decoration.<ref name="PSAS108">{{harvnb|Ritchie|1977}}</ref>
== Cultural significance == Scottish Painted pebbles have been dated to the period 200 AD to the eighth century AD, the Pictish period. They may have been sling-stones that were thought to be of magical nature by the Picts, however local traditions suggest that they were '[[charm-stone]]s', often known as 'Cold-stones'. Such stones were used within living memory to cure sickness in animals and humans.<ref name="PSAS"/>
In the ''Life of [[St. Columba]]'' it is recorded that he visited [[Bridei I of the Picts|King Bridei]] in Pictland in around the year 565 AD and taking a white stone pebble from the [[River Ness]] he blessed it and any water it came into contact with would cure sick people. It floated in water and cured the king from a terminal illness. It remained as one of the great treasures of the king and cured many others.
== See also == *[[Amulets]] *[[Apotrope]] *[[Magic (paranormal)|Magic]] *[[Pebble]] *[[Touch pieces]]

{{lowercase title}} {{Infobox company | name = The simPRO Group Pty Ltd | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = [[Software as a service|Software as a Service (SaaS)]] | founded = 2002 in [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] | founders = Stephen Bradshaw, Vaughan McKillop | hq_location_city = Brisbane | hq_location_country = Australia | area_served = [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom]] | key_people = Sean Diljore (CEO) | products = Global [[Field service management|field management]] software including add-on solutions | website = https://www.simprogroup.com/homepage }}
'''simPRO''' is a private [[Software as a service|SaaS]] company that provides [[Cloud computing|cloud-based]] job and project management software to those in field service and trade contracting industries<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.simpro.com.au|title=Field Service & Job Management Software {{!}} simPRO Australia|website=www.simpro.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>. Their clientele range from [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|SME]] contracting businesses to large-scale enterprises and projects<ref name=":0" />.
The company has a global reach, with customers and partners in [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[United States]]<ref name=":0" />. simPRO offices are located in each of these countries, with the more recent opening for operation in [[Colorado]] in the United States<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metrodenver.org/news/news-center/2016/10/simpro-software-opening-us-headquarters-in-broomfield-that-could-bring-100-jobs/|title=Simpro Software opening U.S. headquarters in Broomfield that could bring 100 jobs {{!}} Metro Denver|website=www.metrodenver.org|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>.
As of the end of 2017, the company services approximately 4,000+ businesses and 100,000+ users<ref name=":0" />.
== History ==
simPRO was founded in 2002, after electrical business owner Steve Bradshaw approached [[software engineering]] student Vaughan McKillop about creating a website for his growing electrical contracting business<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.simprogroup.com/about-us|title=The simPRO Software Story {{!}} simPRO US|website=www.simprogroup.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>. When Vaughn explained to Steve that his strengths lay in writing software rather than web design, Steve quickly realised he could build something big to help his business<ref name=":1" />. Using the web-based [[PHP]] and [[MySQL]] languages that Vaughan knew well, the two men began to create simPRO's first iteration<ref name=":1" />.
Initially they focused on making digital job lists, and then moved on to building a scheduling tool that could allocate time and [[technicians]]<ref name=":1" />. As Vaughan and Steve continued to expand on the software's capability and functionality, they realised that the tool they had created could not only help Steve's business, but many others<ref name=":1" />.
The company first started trading as Acorn Software and Service Management Pty Ltd in 2003, then changed its name is simPRO Software in 2011 and simPRO in 2017<ref name=":1" />.
== Management == At at October, 2018, the simPRO Board of Management and Executive Team has six members: Chief Executive Officer Sean Diljore, Chief Operating Officer & Chief Financial Officer Alan Bignell, Chief Marketing Officer Vanessa Winter, and Chief Technology Officer Jonathan Eastgate.
Peter Darley is currently General Manager for simPRO Australia<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.simpro.com.au/company/au-leadership|title=AU Leadership & Executive Team {{!}} simPRO Australia|website=www.simpro.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>, and Ricky Sevta is General Manager simPRO New Zealand<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.simpro.co.nz/company/nz-leadership|title=NZ Leadership & Executive Team {{!}} simPRO NZ|website=www.simpro.co.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>. In 2009, simPRO was launched in the United Kingdom and it’s current General Manager is Richard Pratley<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.simpro.co.uk/blog/management-announcement|title=simPRO UK {{!}} simPRO Manager Returns Home To Guide UK Expansion|website=www.simpro.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>, who previously managed the New Zealand office. In 2015, the company opened a location in Colorado, United States, in an effort to grow it’s presence in the local market, it’s current President is Glenn Nott.
== Investors ==
In October 2016, simPRO received USD$31 million in capital funding from New York-based [[growth equity]] firm Level Equity.<ref name="Bindi">{{cite web|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/queenslands-simpro-software-raises-au40m-for-international-growth/|title=Queensland's SimPro Software raises AU$40m for international growth|last1=Bindi|first1=Tas|website=ZD Net}}</ref><ref name="AE">{{cite web|url=http://americanentrepreneurship.com/press-releases/simpro-secures-us-31-million-in-funding-to-drive-growth.html|title=simPRO Secures US$31 Million in Funding to Drive Growth|website=American Entrepreneurship}}</ref><ref name="Frayne">{{cite web|url=http://rgcommunications.com.au/simpro-software-appoints-president-us-operations/|title=simPRO Software Appoints President Of US Operations|last1=Frayne|first1=Sophie|accessdate=3 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="Jacinda">{{cite news|last1=Tutty|first1=Jacinda|title=Queensland firm simPRO secures $40m investment to fund US expansion plans|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/business/queensland-firm-simpro-secures-40m-investment-to-fund-us-expansion-plans/news-story/c60b2f72f164dfce01ae528669b5c5f1|work=The Courier Mail|date=12 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Khan|first1=Shaistha|title=simPRO Software nabs AU$40Mn in growth capital from New York-based Level Equity|url=https://thetechportal.com/2016/10/12/simpro-software-nabs-au40mn-growth-capital/|website=Tech Portal}}</ref> It marked the first time the company has accepted external investment since its founding.<ref name="Bindi"/><ref name="Jacinda"/>
Level Equity Partner Benjamin Levin and Principal Charles Chen now sit on the simPRO Board of Directors.<ref name="Crunchbase">{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/simpro-software#/entity|title=simPRO Software|website=Crunchbase}}</ref>
== Mergers and acquisitions ==
In 2013, simPRO acquired vehicle [[fleet tracking]] and management company simTRAC for AUD$2.5 million,<ref name="Crunchbase" /><ref name="simTRAC">{{cite web|title=simPRO acquires vehicle tracking and management company simTRAC FOR $2.5 million|url=https://logisticsmagazine.com.au/simpro-acquires-vehicle-tracking-and-management-company-simtrac-for-2-5-million-3/|website=Logisitics & Materials Handling}}</ref> which is designed to help business managers monitor their work vehicles on the road in real time and minimise travel times.<ref name="simTRAC" />
== Features and services ==
simPRO's key features include quoting and estimating, scheduling, service and project management, inventory management, asset maintenance<ref name="Lightning">{{cite web|title=What is simPRO?|url=http://www.lfltd.co.uk/page/what-is-simpro|website=Lightning Fire}}</ref> and invoicing and payment processing.<ref name="A&D">{{cite web|title=Australian software by simPro a big hit with trade contractors operating remotely|url=http://www.architectureanddesign.com.au/news/infolink/australian-software-by-simpro-a-big-hit-with-trade|website=Architecture & Design}}</ref><ref name="MYOB">{{cite web|title=Add-ons : solutions that make business life easier|url=https://www.myob.com/au/addons/listing/12/simpro/|website=MYOB}}</ref><ref name="Tesltra">{{cite web|last1=Karlovsky|first1=Brian|title=Telstra SNP signs simPRO software for nascent security business|url=http://www.arnnet.com.au/article/556777/telstra-snp-signs-simpro-software-nascent-security-business/|website=ARN}}</ref> Integration with accounting software is designed to eliminate double entry of data, provide transfer of financial data, and assist with financial reporting.<ref name="Lovell">{{cite web|url=http://www.accountingweb.co.uk/tech/accounting-software/simpro-brings-cloud-offering-to-the-uk|title=simPRO brings cloud offering to the UK|last1=Lovell|first1=Robert|website=Accounting Web}}</ref><ref name="MYOB" />
simPRO's mobile applications can be used on smartphones and tablets ([[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] operation systems) to keep remote staff connected with the office.<ref name="NBR">{{cite web|url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/article/simpro-appoints-nz-executive-drive-growth-186041|title=simPRO appoints NZ executive to drive growth|website=The National Business Review}}</ref><ref name="Tesltra" /> With the simPRO Connect app, field users can process payment after a job complete with a customer's credit card.<ref name="NBR" /><ref name="Tesltra" /> The simPRO eForms app can be used to digitise a company's existing paper forms for use in the field.<ref name="NBR" />
simPRO pursues technological advancements and add-on solutions for its customer base by way of innovation such as The Internet Of Things and new Data Feeds for efficient data processing.
simPRO’s add-on solutions include:
* simPRO IoT: an [[Internet of things|Internet of Things]] functionality that allows users to retrofit IoT sensors to any existing devices or infrastructure at minimal costs. It is a platform that incorporates the use of machine learning, proactive action triggering and automation of field service activities<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iothub.com.au/news/simpro-fights-fatbergs-with-iot-495777|title=simPRO fights fatbergs with IoT|website=IoT Hub|access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>. * Data Feed - a solution to third-party integrations. This tool has the ability to extract business data from within simPRO via a user’s emails and automate data entry. It is compatible with [[PDF]], [[CSV (file format)|CSV]], [[TXT record|TXT]] and [[Office Open XML|XLSX]] files and can create or reuse information from customers, suppliers, employees, etc<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/press-release/machine-learning-algorithms-helping-time-poor-businesses-get-on-top-of-data-entry-2018-07-25|title=Machine Learning Algorithms Helping Time-Poor Businesses Get On Top Of Data Entry|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-10-05|language=en-US}}</ref>.
simPRO's support network offers global assistance via phone, online chat, and email.<ref name="NECA">{{cite web|title=simPRO|url=https://neca.asn.au/vic/node/2295|website=NECA}}</ref> Free [[Web conferencing|webinars]] are also available to help users understand the software's functionality and features.<ref name="NECA" />
=== Add-on solutions ===
simPRO Software integrates with a range of [[third-party software components|third-party applications]], such as cloud accounting software [[Sage Group|Sage]], [[Xero (software)|Xero]], [[MYOB (company)|MYOB]], and [[QuickBooks]],<ref name="A&D" /><ref name="Lovell" /><ref name="Jacinda" /><ref name="MYOB" /> IT services such as AppsWiz<ref>{{cite web|title=Like to Partner With Us?|url=http://www.appswiz.com/partner-with-us/|website=AppsWiz}}</ref> compliance apps such as New Zealand's CERTIFi,<ref>{{cite web|title=CERTIFi and simPRO love paperless solutions|url=https://www.certifi.co.nz/simpro|website=CERTIFi}}</ref> and marketing apps such as the United Kingdom's online Marketplace Rated People.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trade industry innovators join forces|url=http://www.cambridgewireless.co.uk/news/article/default.aspx?objid=60996|work=Cambridge Wireless|date=12 October 2016}}</ref>
== Partners == simPRO partners with a large volume of like-minded and innovative local industry [[Trade association|trade associations]] worldwide.
Through these partnerships there is a shared common goal of collaboration to implement efficient processes and effective workflows for businesses globally
== Awards ==
=== 2018 AFR Most Innovative Companies List === In 2018 simPRO was recognised as an example of innovation in Australia and New Zealand, after making the 2018 AFR Most Innovative Companies List. Published annually by [[The Australian Financial Review]], the prestigious list is based on a rigorous assessment process managed by Australia’s leading innovation consultancy, Inventium, in conjunction with a panel of industry expert judges. The full Top 100 list can be viewed [https://www.afr.com/leadership/afr-lists/most-innovative-companies/most-innovative-companies-2018-the-full-list-20180722-h1309n here].
simPRO ranked 86th on the overall list, from over 1,000 nominated organisations across Australia and New Zealand.

[[File:Siyah Qalam Demons1.jpg|thumb|600px|Folio 64, recto; Demons and the dead in ritualistic dance. This scene shows Buddhist influence, especially in the flowing drapery, and wild rhythms of their dance]] The '''''Siyah Qalam''''' or '''''Siāh-Qalam''''' ({{lang-fa|سیاه‌قَلَم}}, {{lang-tr|Siyah Kalem}}, meaning "Black Pen") comprise around 80 extant late 14th and early 15th century miniature [[folios]] and ink drawings (''qalam-siāhi''), paintings and calligraphies, on various material, often silk. Measuring up to 335 x 485 cm, they are generally attributed to Central Asia and bear the strong influence of Chinese art and techniques, as well as symbols of Buddhism and [[Tengrism|Shamanism]], which were both major faiths in the region of Central Asia before the arrival of Islam.<ref name="bb21">Bloom; Blair, 21</ref>
In tone and theme, the images are a highpoint of Persian draughtsmanship and include works from the [[Muzaffarids (Iran)|Mozaffarid]], [[Jalairid Sultanate|Jalāyerid]] and [[Oghuz Turk|Turkmen]] periods.<ref name="irani">"[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/siah-qalam Siāh-Qalam “black pen” the genre of paintings or drawings done in pen and ink; the painters of such drawings]". [[Encyclopædia Iranica]]. Retrieved 27 September 2015</ref> They are sometimes attributed to the [[notname]] Muhammad Siyah Qalam; equivalent in English to the ''Master of the Black Pen''.
The figures span a variety of cultures: Iranian, Turkic, Chinese, [[Mongols|Mongolian]], and [[Mughal Empire|Indian]], and date to the century after reign of the [[Turco-Mongol]] conqueror [[Timur]]. Notable for their intrinsic quality, they contain depictions of diabolic imagery, everyday nomadic life in the Euroasian steppe, and contemporary culture's relationship with the dead.
They are held at the [[Topkapı Palace|Topkapi Saray Library]], Istanbul; parts of the larger ''Diez Albums'' of the [[Berlin State Library]] are closely related.<ref name="bb21" />
==Illustrations== The more fantastical and intensely coloured<ref name="bb225">Bloom; Blair, 225</ref> images seem to conjure the devastation and bleakness of [[Genghis Khan]]'s reign.<ref name="w254" /> The drawings have been described as evidencing the "brutal realism of the draftsmanship [while] the lyricism of the refined delineations is of such intensity that it has been matched only in isolated instances in Buddhist as well as Islamic paintings".<ref name="w25-4">Walther, 254-5</ref> In general the inscribed text is banal and not of comparable quality to the illustrations, either in craft or meaning.<ref name="bb225" />
[[File:Dancing Men Siyah Qalam.jpg|thumb|left|400px|''Dancing Men'']] The compositions are highly expressive, and a number of figures are engaged in ecstatic ritual or dance.<ref name="r37">Robinson, 37</ref> The fantastical monsters are drawn from local Pre-Islamic Central Asian folklore, bearing resemblance to beings of Indian, Chinese and middle Eastern legend as Central Asia lies on the cultural crossroad between the Middle East, South Asia and East Asia.<ref name="w254" /> Many of the earthly scenes depict everyday life in the Central Asian [[Eurasian Steppe|Steppes]] as lived by various ethnic people, most prominent the Turkic and Iranian; washing clothes, blowing fire on a cooker, hanging lines of bows and arrows.<ref name="w255">Walther, 255</ref> The living wear various head-dress and costumes and carry a variety of tools and weapons, and engage in different rituals.<ref name="w254" />
The miniatures bear the heavy influence of Chinese art, subtly in their sinuous lines and fluid rhythms, overtly in the figure's dress in that country's traditional dress. The works are of historical interest because of their depictions of everyday life of the faded world of historic Central Asia; with descriptions of tools, costumes, rituals, headdress, and the treatment of domesticated animals.<ref name="w254" />
The cultic acts, especially the ecstatic movement of the dancing figures, filled with emotion and vehement gestures, according to art historian Ingto Walther show "twisted limb and windining motifs...[and are contrasted by the]...brutal realism that overlies the virtuosity of draftsmanship, the lyricism of the refined delineation is of such intensity that it has been matched in isolated subsequent instances in Buddhist as well as Islamic painting".<ref name="w254">Walther, 254</ref>
==Iconography== The sources for the drawings are uncertain; various parts may be influenced by the [[Shahnameh]] and the biblical [[Solomon]]. In addition, given their often disparate size; their precise function cannot be determined with much certainty, though it might be that they were intended as aids to storytelling, to Royal elites.<ref name="irani" /> {{clear}}
==Provenance== The extant leaves are taken from a number of scrolls that transferred ownership during wars and land occupations. Leaves are recorded in inventories in Istanbul and in the library of Topkapi palace of [[Sultan]] [[Selim I]] as booty from his 1514 Persian adventure.<ref name="w254" />
==Gallery== <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="3"> File:Siyah Qalam Folio 8 Recto.jpg|Daily life of nomads, including men washing clothes, starting a cooking fire and carrying bows and arrows File:Siyah Qalam Boars.jpg|Study of Boars at battle File:Siyah Qalam Performance Scene.jpg|Folio 90, recto; ''Performance Scene'', African File:Siyah Qalam Foilo.jpg|Folio; Demons, the dead and the living at battle File:Siyah Qalam Caravan.jpg|Caravan </gallery>

Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0-1953-0991-1}} * Robinson, B.W. ''Persian Book of Kings: An Epitome of the Shahnama of Firdaws''. Routledge, 2012. {{ISBN|978-0-7007-1618-0}} * Walther, Ingo. ''Codices Illustres''. Berlin: Taschen Verlag, 2001. {{ISBN|978-3-8228-6023-6}} {{refend}}

'''Sociophysiology''' is the "interplay between society and physical functioning" (Freund 1988: 856) involving "collaboration of two neighboring sciences: [[physiology]] and [[sociology]]" ([[Marcel Mauss|Mauss]] 1936: 373).<ref>"Collaboration de deux sciences voisines: physiologie, sociologie" (Mauss 1936: 373). Furthermore, Freund (1988) discusses the work of F. J. Buytendijk (1974), which "is one example of an effort to redefine mechanistic physiology in such a way as to include subjectivity and social existence as interrelated aspects of our physical being" (Freund 1988: 847), such that there exists a "mutually 'conditioning' relation between sociopsychological and biological factors. Social environments 'construct' bodies, which in turn affect social behavior, and this behavior in turn further modifies bodies" (Freund 1988: 849).</ref> In other words, sociophysiology is physiological sociology, a special science that studies the physiological side of human (and other animals') interrelations ([[G. P. Zeliony|Zeliony]] 1912: 405–406).<ref>"Die physische Seite der Wechselbeziehungen der Menschen kann nichtsdestoweniger Gegenstand einer besonderen Naturwissenschaft sein, welche ich als "physiologische Soziologie" oder besser "Soziophysiologie" zu bezeichnen vorschlage" (Zeliony 1912: 405-406). Zeliony’s 1912 paper — the earliest known which uses the term "sociophysiology" and its derivatives, e.g., ''Soziophysiologie'', ''soziophysiologische'', etc. — was originally delivered as a lecture to the Saint Petersburg Philosophical Society on March 19, 1909 (Zeliony 1912: 405). Although Zeliony (1912: 406) attributes the term "sociophysiology" to Russian philosopher [[:ru:Введенский, Александр Иванович (философ)|A. I. Wedensky]], [[Paul von Lilienfeld]], in 1879, published a book titled ''Social Physiology'', which uses throughout the unified concept, conjoined with a dash, "social-physiology" [''social-physiologie''] in addition to the modified substantive, separated by a space, "social physiology" [''sociale Physiologie'']. [[G. P. Zeliony]], a worker in [[Ivan Pavlov|Pavlov's]] lab, took as the starting point for his "future sociophysiology," the study of the "[[reflex]]ive interrelations" [''reflektorischen Wechselbeziehungen''] of humans and other animals (Zeliony 1912: 405; 412–413).</ref>
==Interdisciplinary field of research== In addition to having been termed an "interdisciplinary area for research, an area which demonstrates the concomitant relationship between physiology and social behavior" (Di Mascio et al. 1955: 4), sociophysiology may also be described as "social [[ethology]]" and "social energetics" ([[Emile Waxweiler|Waxweiler]] 1906: 62). That is, the "physiology of reactive phenomena caused by the mutual excitations of individuals of the same species" (Waxweiler 1906: 62).<ref>"Éthologie sociale; énergétique sociale — physiologie des phénomènes réactionnels dus aux excitations mutuelles des individus de même espèce" (Waxweiler 1906: 62).</ref>
The interdisciplinary nature of sociophysiology largely entails a "synthesis of [[psychophysiology]] and [[social interaction]]" (Adler 2002: 884) such that a "socio-psycho-biological study" (Mauss 1936: 386) of "biologico-sociological phenomena" (Mauss 1936: 385) may ensue.<ref>"Étude socio-psycho-biologique" (Mauss 1936: 386); "phénomènes biologico-sociologiques" (Mauss 1936: 385).</ref> Such "socio-psycho-biological study" has uncovered a "sharing of physiology between people involved in a meaningful interaction" (Adler 2002: 884), as well as "mutually responsive physiologic engagement having normative function in maintaining social cohesion and well-being in higher social animals" (Adler 2002: 885). This "mutually responsive physiologic engagement" brings into play the "close links uniting social phenomena to the biological phenomena from which they immediately derive" ([[Ernest Solvay|Solvay]] 1906: 26).<ref>"Liens étroits qui unissent les phénomènes sociologiques aux phénomènes biologiques dont ils dérivent immédiatement" (Solvay 1906: 26).</ref>
==Interpersonal physiology== Furthermore, sociophysiology explores the "intimate relationship and mutual regulation between social and physiological systems that is especially vital in human groups" (Barchas 1986: 210). In other words, sociophysiology studies the "physio- and psycho-energetic phenomena at the basis of social groupings" (Solvay 1906: 25).<ref>"Phénomènes physic- et psycho-énergétiques à la base des groupements sociaux" (Rolvaag 1906: 25). Such phenomena are now known to involve [[neurotransmitter]]s, [[hormone]]s, [[pheromone]]s, the [[immune system]], etc.</ref> Along these lines, Zeliony (1912) noted that
{{cquote|The changes of society are the result of the activities of the nervous system. Excitations vary with the same animal and with the same class of animals. The problem of the socio-physiologist is to find out what are the excitors and what the inhibitors. Physiology gives the laws of the nervous system.... Thus the duty of the socio-physiologist is to give a description of the nervous processes of groups which have resulted in changes in the [physical and social] environment.|4=[[Georgii Zeliony|Georgii Pavlovich Zeliony]] |5=summarized in Ellwood, C. A. (1916). Objectivism in sociology. American Journal of Sociology, vol. 22, no. 3, p. 297-298.}}
In addition, sociophysiology "describes structure-function relationships for body structures and interactive functions relevant to psychiatric illness" (Gardner 1997: 351), and also "assumes that psychiatric disorders are pathological variants of the motivation, emotions, and conflict involved in normal communicational processes" (Gardner and Price 1999: 247–248). [[Psychiatry]], thus, involves the diagnosis and treatment of what [[Paul von Lilienfeld|Lilienfeld]] (1879: 280) termed "physiological social pathology", and may be classed as a subfield of sociophysiology, called "pathological sociophysiology" by Zeliony (1912: 405).<ref>"Die physiologische Socialpathologie" (Lilienfeld 1879: 280); "Pathologische Soziophysiologie" (Zeliony 1912: 405).</ref> As summarized by Ellwood (1916), Zeliony thought that, in the future,
{{cquote|A socio-physiological pathology will become necessary. Its field of observation will be the deviations from the norm which are observed either as a result of the pathological differences in the organism or as a result of other conditions, as in the insane or those addicted to the use of alcohol.|4=[[Georgii Zeliony|Georgii Pavlovich Zeliony]]|5=Ellwood, C. A. (1916). Objectivism in sociology. American Journal of Sociology, vol. 22, no. 3, p. 298.}}
Ellwood (1916: 298) also noted that Zeliony's future sociophysiology, being a natural biological science, must be [[Darwinism|Darwinian]].
In short, sociophysiology is "reciprocal, interpersonal physiology" (Adler 2002: 885). Such interpersonal physiology may have implications in the realm of human politics. For example, the findings of a recent study "suggest that political attitudes vary with physiological traits linked to divergent manners of experiencing and processing environmental threats" (Oxley et al. 2008: 1669).

No people were harmed in the incident. |[[Islamists]] (suspected) |- |2006 |Arrest |0 |13 (arrested) |In 2006 the [[Norwegian Police Security Service]] (PST) in cooperation with Italian police expelled thirteen members of [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] from Norway.{{Cite news|title=PST aksjonerte mot 25 islamister etter terrorsamtaler i Oslo|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/05/15/nyheter/terrorisme/politiets_sikkerhetstjeneste/oslo/islamisme/6244375/|work=Dagbladet|date=15 May 2015|language=Norwegian}} |[[Al-Qaeda]] |- |2009 |Attempted terror plot |0 |25 (arrested) |In 2009 the Norwegian Police Security Service (PST) [[Abdul Rauf Mohammad|actioned against 25 Islamists]] thought to have planned terror in Norway. |[[Islamists]] |- |2010 |Atempted terror plot, arrest |0 |3 (arrested) |The [[2010 Norway terror plot]] in which three Islamists were arrested and later convicted for terror plans. |[[Al-Qaeda]] (suspected) |- |25 January, 2010 |Shooting, assassination attempt |0 |1 |Mullah Krekar's son-in-law was injured when it was shot against the former guerrilla leader's apartment in Tøyen in Oslo, on the night of January the 25th. August 29, 2012] |[[Mullah Krekar]] |- |24 July, 2014 |Attempted terror plot |0 |0 |The [[2014 Norway terror plot|2014 terror threat]] by jihadists from the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (ISIL) which caused extraordinary short-term security measures in Norway.[[Verdens Gang|VG Nett]]: [http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/authorities-warned-of-terror-attack-against-norway-within-few-days/a/23260410/ Authorities warned of terror attack against Norway "within few days"][[Verdens Gang|VG Nett]]: http://www.vg.no/nyheter/innenriks/terrorangrepet-i-koebenhavn/oekte-sikkerhetstiltak-i-norge-etter-koebenhavn-terror/a/23396304/ |[[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] |- |8 April, 2017 |Attempted bombing |0 |0 |On 8 April 2017 in the aftermath of the [[2017 Stockholm attack]], a man was arrested and part of the [[Grønland, Oslo|Grønland]] district of [[Oslo]] closed off by police after a "bomb-like" device was found that was later demolished in a controlled explosion.{{Cite news|title=Norway police destroy suspect device in Oslo|url=https://www.thelocal.no/20170409/norway-police-destroy-suspect-device-in-oslo|website=The Local|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=9 April 2017}} The man, a 17-year-old Russian citizen, was charged on 9 April with illegal possession of an explosive device. The man arrived in Norway as an asylum seeker in 2010, and was known to the [[Norwegian Police Security Service]] (PST) for having expressed support for the Islamic State. The events led PST to raise the terror alert.{{Cite news|title=PST: Sannsynlig med terrorangrep i Norge de neste to månedene|url=https://www.nrk.no/norge/pst_-sannsynlig-med-terrorangrep-i-norge-de-neste-to-manedene-1.13468445|publisher=[[NRK]]|date=9 April 2017|language=Norwegian}} |[[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] (suspected) |- |28 September, 2018 |Bioterrorism |0 |0 |Four persons at a military camp in [[Kolsås]] were taken to the hospital, after opening a suspicious package. The police suspected Islamic fundamentalists to be behind the attack.https://www.nrk.no/ostlandssendingen/kolsas-leir_-ingenting-farlig-i-den-mistenkelige-pakken-1.14227742 |[[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]] (suspected) |- |13 November, 2018 |Terror threats |0 |1 (arrested) |On Tuesday morning the 13 November 2018, Norwegian Islamist Mohyeldeen Mohammad was arrested at his home after agreement with PST. {{Infobox ethnic group| |group =Trinidadian and Tobagonian Canadians |image = |caption = |total =68,225 {{small|(2011)}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/dt-td/Rp-eng.cfm?LANG=E&APATH=3&DETAIL=0&DIM=0&FL=A&FREE=0&GC=0&GID=0&GK=0&GRP=1&PID=105396&PRID=0&PTYPE=105277&S=0&SHOWALL=0&SUB=0&Temporal=2013&THEME=95&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=|title=2011 National Household Survey: Data tables|accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> |popplace= [[Ontario]], [[Alberta]], [[Quebec]], [[Manitoba]] |rels =[[Hindu]], [[Muslim]], [[Christianity]], [[Rastafari movement|Rastafari]] |related =[[Black Canadians]], [[Indo-Canadians]], [[African Trinidadian]]s, [[Indo-Trinidadian]]s, [[Chinese Trinidadian]]s, [[Trinidadian Americans]], [[Trinidadian British]], [[Trinidadian Australian]] }} '''Trinidadian and Tobagonian Canadians''' are [[Canadians|Canadian]] citizens who are fully or partially of [[Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidadian and Tobagonian]] descent or a person having those origins and hold the Canadian citizenship. There were over 68,000 Trinidadian and Tobagonian Canadians in 2011, with majority of them live in Toronto, specifically in the [[Thistletown]] and [[Eglinton West]] neighbourhoods as well as throughout [[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]].
==Notable Trinidadian and Tobagonian Canadians==

'''Ukrainians in Estonia''' (Ukrainian: Українці в Естонії; Estonian: Eesti ukrainlased) are the [[Demographics of Estonia|third largest etnic group in Estonia]] after Estonians and Russians and number 28,000<ref>http://euromaidanpress.com/2017/10/05/volunteers-took-a-heavy-burden-from-the-state-how-ukraines-diaspora-in-estonia-helps-fight-russias-hybrid-war/</ref>. 4,000 out of them are citizens of Ukraine.
Most of the Ukrainians in Estonia live in [[Tallinn]] (2,92% of the whole population) and [[Harjumaa]]; some live in [[Tartu]] and [[Pärnu]]. The representatives of the Ukrainian ethnic minority have formed over 20 national-cultural organizations. <ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://estonia.mfa.gov.ua/ua/ukraine-ee/ukrainians-in-ee|title=Українці в Естонії - Посольство України в Естонській Республіці|publisher=estonia.mfa.gov.ua|language=ua|accessdate=2017-03-10}}</ref> Most of the Ukrainians in Estonia support the integration of non-Estonians into Estonian society, while retaining their own cultural and ethnic particularities. For the Estonian population of Estonia, on Saturdays the fourth channel of the [[Estonian Radio]] (the Russian language channel) broadcasts Ukrainian language radio broadcast «Червона калина» ('Chervona kalina' - "Red Viburnum").

[[Image:Urairat Soimee.jpg|right|thumb|Urairat Soimee in Thailand several months before her death.]] {{Moresources|date=June 2014}} '''Urairat Soimee''' (อุไรรัตน์ สร้อยมี) (1968 – 2006) was a victim of [[human trafficking]] in [[Japan]]. She was from [[Phetchabun]]'s Lom Sak district in [[Thailand]] and had lived in [[Yokkaichi|Yokkaichi, Mie Prefecture, Japan]], where she was forced into [[prostitution]]. She was incarcerated for several years in a Japanese prison until she was released in September 2005 due to the development of a terminal form of [[ovarian cancer]]. She was allowed to return to her hometown in Thailand to spend her final days with her family. Upon her return, Soimee filed a civil lawsuit against her traffickers in Thailand, reported to be the first suit of its kind in the country. However, she died in May 2006 before the case was adjudicated. Her adoptive mother has said that she will continue her case in court. ==Background== Urairat Soimee was born in the [[Lom_Sak_District|Lom Sak]] district of Phetchabun, Thailand. She had three children and a husband, who became disabled due to a car accident. Like many women in her village, she was poor and had little formal education. She went by the nickname "Bua", which means "lotus flower" in Thai. She was recruited to work in Japan by a wealthy neighbor, Patama Kosaka, an alleged childhood friend of Soimee's mother. Kosaka claimed she was married to a Japanese man and that she owned a Thai restaurant in Japan where she wanted Soimee to work as a waitress. The girl had no radio or television and little formal education, and therefore was not aware of the many cases in which women from Thailand were tricked or coerced into prostitution abroad. {{cn|date=June 2014}} ==Forced prostitution in Japan== Soimee arrived in Japan in 2000 and was transported to [[Yokkaichi]] by a Thai woman named Dao and her husband, where she was told that she would have to work as a prostitute. When she protested, she was told that if she did not comply, she would be sold to a brothel on an island and thrown into the sea if she tried to escape. Soimee was told that she could leave after paying off her debt within five months. During this time, she was locked in the apartment with other Thai sex slaves, and taken out by Dao and her husband to hotel rooms to service customers, ranging from three to six a day. Soimee was forced to service customers even when menstruating, and after having contracted a painful sexually transmitted disease. {{cn|date=June 2014}} However, at the end of five months, Dao refused to release her, saying that she had been sold to another [[yakuza]] gang and that her debt had increased. It was at that point that Soimee reportedly contacted another Thai sex slave, Pranee, and a Thai friend, Boon, to help her escape. {{cn|date=June 2014}} ==Escape and incarceration== The circumstances surrounding Dao's death and Urairat's escape are disputed. In an interview with the ''[[Bangkok Post]]'', Soimee claimed that Boon, her friend, came to the apartment and helped her escape, and that Boon eventually killed Dao to prevent her from going to the yakuza. However, the [[Kyodo]] news service reported that Japanese prosecutors accused Soimee of robbery and murder by smashing Dao's head with a bottle.[http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/01/23/national/index.php?news=national_19721754.html Woman's dying wish: to punish traffickers who ruined her life] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312032349/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/01/23/national/index.php?news=national_19721754.html |date=2007-03-12 }}, nationmultimedia.com, 23 January 2006; accessed 10 June 2014. Despite pleas from human rights organizations, Boon was sentenced to 10 years in prison for his role in the murder, and Soimee was sentenced for seven years. While in prison, Soimee was diagnosed with advanced ovarian cancer and released from custody to spend her remaining days with her family in Thailand.[http://blog.silveradomedia.com/?p=89 Profile of Urairat Soimee], silveradomedia.com; accessed 10 June 2014. ==Court battle and final days== Patama and her parents, the three traffickers who deceived Soimee and Pranee into coming to Japan, were sentenced to 13 years imprisonment in criminal court. Soimee filed a 4.6 million baht civil lawsuit against the three, reported to be the first of its kind in Thailand. However, she died in May 2006 before her case was adjudicated. Her adoptive mother, Lamyai Kaewkerd, vowed to continue her battle in court. Upon her return to Thailand, Soimee became a strong voice against human trafficking, leading a campaign that urged other victims to step forward. She earned an award from Thailand's Social Development and Human Security Ministry in March 2006 to celebrate International Women's Day for her work in fighting human trafficking.
"My wish is for the government and all sides to get tough with human trafficking rackets, the same way it suppresses drugs", she was quoted as saying. "I want my last wish to be fulfilled. It is not only a gift for me, but also for women in general because they shouldn't live through a hellish experience like I have."{{cn|date=June 2014}}
